title: Is this sentence 'I'm sure to have done the work by tomorrow' correct and referring to the future? - Quora

response.answer_text: Original Question: Is this sentence "I'm sure to have done the work by tomorrow" correct and referring to the future? Your construction would depend on what you’re trying to communicate. If you’re simply trying to convey your plan to finish the work tomorrow, you’d use a future tense for the “be sure” part and a past tense for the “have done” part:“I’ll be sure to have done the work by tomorrow.”While this is correct grammatically, there is something wonky about having a future tense followed by past tense like this. It might sound more natural if you changed the “done” part to be associated with the work instead:“I’ll be sure to have the work done by tomorrow.”In the first example, the confidence in getting the work done won’t exist until the future. However, if your intent is to emphasize that your confidence in the work exists right now, the “be sure” part should be present tense and the “have done” part would shift to the future:“I’m sure that I’ll have done the work by tomorrow.”

I'm sure I'll finish the work by tomorrowI'm sure the work would be done by tomorrowI am sure the work will be done by tomorrowWe use have done in the present and the past have-done. Verb. (third-person singular simple present has done, present participle having done, simple past and past participle had done) To reach an end; to finish (with).

“I’m sure to have done the work by tomorrow” wouldn’t be correct. You wouldn’t say “to have done” in reference to work you will do tomorrow or anytime in the future. You should say, “I’m sure that I will have the work done by tomorrow.”
"I'm sure we would have done the work by tomorrow." Is correct.
